summary: The U.S. House of Representatives, acting through its Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA), played an oversight and investigative role related to the JFK assassination. The documents provided are payroll certifications and reports for the HSCA, indicating the committee's operational status and staffing during its investigation. These documents span from November 1977 to September 1978, reflecting the period when the HSCA was actively conducting its inquiry. The documents primarily serve as administrative records, detailing employee compensation and positions within the committee.
significance: The U.S. House of Representatives' significance in the JFK context lies in its establishment and oversight of the HSCA, which was tasked with investigating the circumstances surrounding President Kennedy's assassination. The payroll documents highlight the operational aspects of the HSCA, demonstrating the committee's active engagement in its investigative duties during the specified timeframe.
